Award.AbstractNarration:
The PI investigates questions concerning the variational theory of minimal submanifolds and its applications. Minimal surfaces are among the most natural objects in differential geometry. They have encountered striking applications in many other fields, like three-dimensional topology, mathematical physics, complex and conformal geometry, among others. In general relativity minimal surfaces appear as models for the apparent horizons of black holes. The minimal surface equation plays a very important role as a model for several kinds of nonlinear phenomena in nature. Significant progress in this area has always had a great impact in mathematical analysis and the physical sciences. The research of this project will advance our basic understanding of minimal surfaces and their general existence theory. It concerns foundational questions about when these objects exist and how their properties relate to features of the ambient space.

This research project contains a number of problems at the interface between geometry, analysis and the calculus of variations. One of the project's goals is to develop a good understanding of the Morse-theoretic properties of the space of minimal varieties in a given Riemannian manifold. This is to be accomplished by a combination of min-max techniques and topological methods, where the relevant spaces of cycles are defined by means of geometric measure theory. The PI will study the existence and basic properties, like the Morse index, of min-max minimal varieties.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project has supported research of the PI and of PhD students at Princeton University. The main topic has been the existence theory of minimal surfaces, but some other subjects like Ricci flow have also been studied.  Minimal surfaces are central objects in Differential Geometry and their study goes back to the 1700s. The simplest physical model for a minimal surface is a soap film. The equation governing these surfaces is very fundamental so minimal surfaces also appear in General Relativity, biology, architecture and other applied domains. These surfaces are in equilibrium with respect to forces that tend to minimize the surface area. There is a long list of beautiful examples in three-dimensional Euclidean space. The purpose of the research supported by this grant has been to construct these objects in more general spaces, more specifically non-Euclidean geometries which could be curved (Riemann spaces).  The most appealing question is to look for closed surfaces, meaning they close up in themselves like the surface of a sphere or of a torus. There is a theory finished up in the early 1980s that could construct one closed minimal surface in every Riemannian manifold (also assumed to be closed). As a result of the project supported by this grant we have been able to go significantly beyond. We know that there are always infinitely many such surfaces in every space, and that for typical (meaning most) spaces there are so many that they actually  fill up space. There is even a collection of these surfaces that distributes evenly in the manifold. We have discovered that the areas of these surfaces determine the volume of surrounding space, just like the frequencies of a drum determine its area. We have developed a Morse theory for the problem, which means understanding the reasons these objects exist from purely topological principles. The Phd students supported by this project have secured postdoctoral positions at prestigious universities. Many other students and young researchers have been attracted by the developments. With the help of this project they are now prepared to motivate and educate a new generation of undergraduate and graduate students, who will soon turn into outstanding professionals in society.
